column4: Our results, taken in conjunction with recent research, provide a basis for recommendation of aspirin chemoprevention in Lynch syndrome as standard of care.
column6: For anyone considering taking aspirin I would recommend discussing this with your GP first as aspirin is known to bring with it a risk of stomach complaints, including ulcers
column7: healthy middle-Maged people who start taking aspirin around the age of 45 or 50 for 20 to 30 years could expect to reap the most benefit
column8: For anyone considering taking aspirin I would recommend discussing this with their GP first as aspirin brings with it a risk of ulcers
column9: sufferers should consult first with their GP
column10: people with a family history of bowel cancer may want to start taking a low dose of aspirin as a preventative measure after first discussing it with their doctor
column11: Before anyone begins to take aspirin on a regular basis they should consult their doctor as aspirin is known to bring with it a risk of stomach complaints, including ulcers
column12: Anyone thinking of taking the drug regularly should consult their doctor first
column13: those with Lynch Syndrome should start taking aspirin from the age of 20, as they can develop cancers well before middle age
column33: People who've got a clear family history of, particularly, bowel cancer should seriously consider adding low dose aspirin to their routine and particularly those people who've got a genetic predisposition
column37: For the general population, taking low-dose aspirin might be a more sensible option
column39: But researchers say it could be a risk worth taking for people with high cancer susceptibility

column11: Before anyone begins to take aspirin on a regular basis they should consult their doctor as aspirin is known to bring with it a risk of stomach complaints, including ulcers; Tens of thousands of people at risk of bowel cancer should start taking aspirin daily; people may want to weigh up the cost benefits

column13: those with Lynch Syndrome should start taking aspirin from the age of 20, as they can develop cancers well before middle age, Prof Rothwell consequently suggested everybody should consider taking low dose aspirin daily from the age of 45

column37: For the general population, taking low-dose aspirin might be a more sensible option; supported more general recommendations to consider aspirin for preventing bowel cancer, based on individual patients' risks
